prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity:
We have used an average upper limit RMS noise temperature from Pulliam et al. (2012), along with the receiver gain for the NRAO 12 m telescope used in those observations, to calculate an expected peak upper limit flux of ~240 mJy. The requested sensitivity of 9 mJy provies a 3 sigma detection for NH2OH abundances as much as 8 times less than the upper limit established by Pulliam et al. (2012), and is an ideal balance between achievable sensitivity and integration time for this correlator setup.
The emitting region of the target source, IRAS 16293, is expected to be quite compact, on the order of a few arcseconds. The requested angular resolution of 1" is therefore provides both the resolving power to examine any clumpy structure that might be present, while still being well-matched to the overall source size.
Spectral lines in IRAS 16293 have been shown to vary largely in width, but we expect to find lines no narrower than 1 km/s. We have therefore requested appropriate bandwidths to provide 4 resolution elements across the 1 km/s FWHM. This will provide sufficient resolution to perform the Guassian fits necessary to extract accurate line parameters (namely peak intensity and linewidth).
Imaging:
IRAS 16293 has two compact cores where NH2OH is expected to be detected. These cores are of the order a few arcseconds in diameter and are separated by about the same. Thus, the entirety of the region of interest is easily located within the primary beam of the telescope and is also less than the maximum recoverable scale for this configuration. As a result, we expect no significant loss of sensitivity.
Correlator Setup:
We have configured the correlator to target the NH2OH J = 3-2 branch for identification purposes, and selected an appropriate bandwidth, centered on the 151.1 GHz transition, to cover all desired lines at the appropriate velocity resolution. We also target several transitions of methanol with a range of upper state energies to provide a probe of temperature and a point of abundance comparison with NH2OH. Finally, we target a single transition of formaldehyde, the production mechanism of which is similar to NH2OH but using CO rather than NO as a precursor, as noted in the scientific justification. This allows for a direct comparison of these reactive pathways in this environment.
Calibration:
We have chosen the system-defined calibration as recommended.
Bandpass accuracy: We expect no complications in this regard.
Scheduling/time constraints: We have no scheduling or time constraints.
Data rate: Our data rate is within normal standards.
Special constraints on standard observing modes: On-source time, and total observing time are all within norms. Our overheads are only a few percentage points over the recommended 30%.

Sensitivity:
We have used an average upper limit RMS noise temperature from Pulliam et al. (2012), along with the receiver gain for the NRAO 12 m telescope used in those observations, to calculate an expected peak upper limit flux of ~240 mJy. The requested sensitivity of 9 mJy provies a 3 sigma detection for NH2OH abundances as much as 8 times less than the upper limit established by Pulliam et al. (2012), and is an ideal balance between achievable sensitivity and integration time for this correlator setup.
The emitting region of the target source, NGC 6334I, is expected to be quite compact, on the order of a few arcseconds. The requested angular resolution of 1" is therefore provides both the resolving power to examine any clumpy structure that might be present, while still being well-matched to the overall source size.
Spectral lines in NGC 6334I have been shown to vary in width. On average, we expect to find lines of ~5 km/s, but as low as 2 km/s. We have therefore requested appropriate bandwidths to provide 4 resolution elements across the 2 km/s FWHM. This will provide sufficient resolution to perform the Guassian fits necessary to extract accurate line parameters (namely peak intensity and linewidth).
Imaging:
NGC 6334I has a single compact core where NH2OH is expected to be detected. This core is of the order a few arcseconds in diameter. Thus, the entirety of the region of interest is easily located within the primary beam of the telescope and is also less than the maximum recoverable scale for this configuration. As a result, we expect no significant loss of sensitivity.
Correlator Setup:
We have configured the correlator to target the NH2OH J = 3-2 branch for identification purposes, and selected an appropriate bandwidth, centered on the 151.1 GHz transition, to cover all desired lines at the appropriate velocity resolution. We also target several transitions of methanol with a range of upper state energies to provide a probe of temperature and a point of abundance comparison with NH2OH. Finally, we target a single transition of formaldehyde, the production mechanism of which is similar to NH2OH but using CO rather than NO as a precursor, as noted in the scientific justification. This allows for a direct comparison of these reactive pathways in this environment.
Calibration:
We have chosen the system-defined calibration as recommended.
Bandpass accuracy: We expect no complications in this regard.
Scheduling/time constraints: We have no scheduling or time constraints.
Data rate: Our data rate is within normal standards.
Special constraints on standard observing modes: On-source time, and total observing time are all within norms. Our overheads are only a few percentage points over the recommended 30%.

Sensitivity:
We have used an average upper limit RMS noise temperature from Pulliam et al. (2012), along with the receiver gain for the NRAO 12 m telescope used in those observations, to calculate an expected peak upper limit flux of ~240 mJy. The requested sensitivity of 6 mJy provies a 4 sigma detection for NH2OH abundances as much as 8 times less than the upper limit established by Pulliam et al. (2012), and is an ideal balance between achievable sensitivity and integration time for this correlator setup.
BHR 71 is a broad, extended outflow. However, as detailed in the science justification, we are targeting the much narrower region of peak SiO emission associated with the shock. We expect this region to be relatively compact on the order of a few to ten arcseconds. The requested angular resolution of 1" is therefore provides both the resolving power to examine the clumpy structure that will likely be present, while still being relatively well-matched to the overall source size.
Spectral lines in BHR 71 have been shown to vary in width, but we expect them to be ~2 km/s. We have therefore requested appropriate bandwidths to provide 4 resolution elements across the 2 km/s FWHM. This will provide sufficient resolution to perform the Guassian fits necessary to extract accurate line parameters (namely peak intensity and linewidth).
Imaging:
While BHR 71 is a large (tens of arcminutes) outflow, the regions of interest, that is the shocked regions indicated by peak SiO emission, is expected to be relatively compact, on the order of a few to ten arcseconds. Thus, the entirety of the region of interest is easily located within the primary beam of the telescope and is also less than the maximum recoverable scale for this configuration. As a result, we expect no significant loss of sensitivity.
Correlator Setup:
We have configured the correlator to target the NH2OH J = 3-2 branch for identification purposes, and selected an appropriate bandwidth, centered on the 151.1 GHz transition, to cover all desired lines at the appropriate velocity resolution. We also target several transitions of methanol with a range of upper state energies to provide a probe of temperature and a point of abundance comparison with NH2OH. Finally, we target a single transition of formaldehyde, the production mechanism of which is similar to NH2OH but using CO rather than NO as a precursor, as noted in the scientific justification. This allows for a direct comparison of these reactive pathways in this environment.
Calibration:
We have chosen the system-defined calibration as recommended.
Bandpass accuracy: We expect no complications in this regard.
Scheduling/time constraints: We have no scheduling or time constraints.
Data rate: Our data rate is within normal standards.
Special constraints on standard observing modes: On-source time, and total observing time are all within norms. Our overheads are only a few percentage points over the recommended 30%.

Sensitivity:
We have used an average upper limit RMS noise temperature from Pulliam et al. (2012), along with the receiver gain for the NRAO 12 m telescope used in those observations, to calculate an expected peak upper limit flux of ~240 mJy. The requested sensitivity of 9 mJy provies a 3 sigma detection for NH2OH abundances as much as 8 times less than the upper limit established by Pulliam et al. (2012), and is an ideal balance between achievable sensitivity and integration time for this correlator setup.
The emitting region of the target source, IRAS 16293, is expected to be quite compact, on the order of a few arcseconds. The requested angular resolution of 1" is therefore provides both the resolving power to examine any clumpy structure that might be present, while still being well-matched to the overall source size.
Spectral lines in IRAS 16293 have been shown to vary largely in width, but we expect to find lines no narrower than 1 km/s. We have therefore requested appropriate bandwidths to provide 4 resolution elements across the 1 km/s FWHM. This will provide sufficient resolution to perform the Guassian fits necessary to extract accurate line parameters (namely peak intensity and linewidth).
Imaging:
IRAS 16293 has two compact cores where NH2OH is expected to be detected. These cores are of the order a few arcseconds in diameter and are separated by about the same. Thus, the entirety of the region of interest is easily located within the primary beam of the telescope and is also less than the maximum recoverable scale for this configuration. As a result, we expect no significant loss of sensitivity.
Correlator Setup:
We have configured the correlator to target the NH2OH J = 5-4 branch and J = 2(1,1)-1(0,1) transition for identification purposes. The bandwidth chosen provides sufficient coverage, at the desired velocity resolution, to cover all the NH2OH lines in the target range. We also target several transitions of methanol, centered around the listed transition at 266.3 GHz, with a range of upper state energies to provide a probe of temperature and a point of abundance comparison with NH2OH.
Calibration:
We have chosen the system-defined calibration as recommended.
Bandpass accuracy: We expect no complications in this regard.
Scheduling/time constraints: We have no scheduling or time constraints.
Data rate: Our data rate is within normal standards.
Special constraints on standard observing modes: On-source time, and total observing time are all within norms. Our overheads are only a few percentage points over the recommended 30%.

Sensitivity:
We have used an average upper limit RMS noise temperature from Pulliam et al. (2012), along with the receiver gain for the NRAO 12 m telescope used in those observations, to calculate an expected peak upper limit flux of ~240 mJy. The requested sensitivity of 6 mJy provies a 4 sigma detection for NH2OH abundances as much as 8 times less than the upper limit established by Pulliam et al. (2012), and is an ideal balance between achievable sensitivity and integration time for this correlator setup.
The emitting region of the target source, NGC 6334I, is expected to be quite compact, on the order of a few arcseconds. The requested angular resolution of 1" is therefore provides both the resolving power to examine any clumpy structure that might be present, while still being well-matched to the overall source size.
Spectral lines in NGC 6334I have been shown to vary in width. On average, we expect to find lines of ~5 km/s, but as low as 2 km/s. We have therefore requested appropriate bandwidths to provide 4 resolution elements across the 2 km/s FWHM. This will provide sufficient resolution to perform the Guassian fits necessary to extract accurate line parameters (namely peak intensity and linewidth).
Imaging:
NGC 6334I has a single compact core where NH2OH is expected to be detected. This core is of the order a few arcseconds in diameter. Thus, the entirety of the region of interest is easily located within the primary beam of the telescope and is also less than the maximum recoverable scale for this configuration. As a result, we expect no significant loss of sensitivity.
Correlator Setup:
We have configured the correlator to target the NH2OH J = 5-4 branch and J = 2(1,1)-1(0,1) transition for identification purposes. The bandwidth chosen provides sufficient coverage, at the desired velocity resolution, to cover all the NH2OH lines in the target range. We also target several transitions of methanol, centered around the listed transition at 266.3 GHz, with a range of upper state energies to provide a probe of temperature and a point of abundance comparison with NH2OH.
Calibration:
We have chosen the system-defined calibration as recommended.
Bandpass accuracy: We expect no complications in this regard.
Scheduling/time constraints: We have no scheduling or time constraints.
Data rate: Our data rate is within normal standards.
Special constraints on standard observing modes: On-source time, and total observing time are all within norms. Our overheads are only a few percentage points over the recommended 30%.

Sensitivity:
We have used an average upper limit RMS noise temperature from Pulliam et al. (2012), along with the receiver gain for the NRAO 12 m telescope used in those observations, to calculate an expected peak upper limit flux of ~240 mJy. The requested sensitivity of 9 mJy provies a 3 sigma detection for NH2OH abundances as much as 8 times less than the upper limit established by Pulliam et al. (2012), and is an ideal balance between achievable sensitivity and integration time for this correlator setup.
BHR 71 is a broad, extended outflow. However, as detailed in the science justification, we are targeting the much narrower region of peak SiO emission associated with the shock. We expect this region to be relatively compact on the order of a few to ten arcseconds. The requested angular resolution of 1" is therefore provides both the resolving power to examine the clumpy structure that will likely be present, while still being relatively well-matched to the overall source size.
Spectral lines in BHR 71 have been shown to vary in width, but we expect them to be ~2 km/s. We have therefore requested appropriate bandwidths to provide 4 resolution elements across the 2 km/s FWHM. This will provide sufficient resolution to perform the Guassian fits necessary to extract accurate line parameters (namely peak intensity and linewidth).
Imaging:
While BHR 71 is a large (tens of arcminutes) outflow, the regions of interest, that is the shocked regions indicated by peak SiO emission, is expected to be relatively compact, on the order of a few to ten arcseconds. Thus, the entirety of the region of interest is easily located within the primary beam of the telescope and is also less than the maximum recoverable scale for this configuration. As a result, we expect no significant loss of sensitivity.
Correlator Setup:
We have configured the correlator to target the NH2OH J = 2-1 branch for identification purposes. We also target several transitions of methanol with a range of upper state energies to provide a probe of temperature and a point of abundance comparison with NH2OH. Finally, we target a single transition of SiO. The peak of SiO emission, taken from previous studies, has informed our target location as it is known to be an excellent tracer of the shocked region we wish to target. Understanding its spatial distribution, at the same angular resolution as NH2OH, is therefore critical to understanding the physical processes that give rise to any observed NH2OH emission.
Calibration:
We have chosen the system-defined calibration as recommended.
Bandpass accuracy: We expect no complications in this regard.
Scheduling/time constraints: We have no scheduling or time constraints.
Data rate: Our data rate is within normal standards.
Special constraints on standard observing modes: On-source time, and total observing time are all within norms. Our overheads are only a few percentage points over the recommended 30%.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The aim of this project is the first detection of hydroxylamine (NH2OH) in the interstellar medium - particularly in star- and planet-forming regions. NH2OH is an important precursor in space for the formation of amino acids - the corner stones among the building blocks of life. Abundances within reach of ALMA are predicted from very recent laboratory experiments in our group that have focused on the solid state chemistry of nitrogen oxides in interstellar ice analogues. Our results show that for low temperatures, NO and NO2 ices are readily converted into NH2OH upon hydrogenation, yielding a stable end-product. In warmer environments, NH2OH can thermally desorb yielding detectable gas-phase abundances. The high desorption temperature of NH2OH (120 K) makes compact (few arcsecond) thermally heated and shocked regions the most likely sites to detect NH2OH emission. Only ALMA has the combined sensitivity and angular resolution necessary to identify this important species. The characteristic hyperfine pattern will guide such an identification. This is an important step toward the astrochemical quantification of amino acid formation in the interstellar medium.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology
